text:
Hi! Quick question. 

A potential client is asking me to help him with writing the overall description of his podcast. 

What do I charge for this? Anyone done this kind of writing before? Any advice helps!

elements.text: Hi! Quick question.
A potential client is asking me to help him with writing the overall description of his podcast.
What do I charge for this? Anyone done this kind of writing before? Any advice helps!

text: Depends on the amount of work involved.

elements.text: Depends on the amount of work involved.

text:
Just to write a description, I would say $40 - $60.

If some research is involved, say keywords, competitors tec, would go up to $200

text: SEO-ish question: My expertise is definitely more in content than SEO and I recently took on a site that is essentially a landing page. It obviously needs content, but the problem the client really wants to fix is that when you Google the name of the site (it's not a local business), it doesn't show up. I'm guessing that's because it has zero links and content, so my first step is just building out service pages and getting links to those. All of the pages are correctly indexed and it does show up in the search results for the brand name (it's just not first). Does anybody have any input or would take a different approach towards this? Thanks!

elements.text: SEO-ish question: My expertise is definitely more in content than SEO and I recently took on a site that is essentially a landing page. It obviously needs content, but the problem the client really wants to fix is that when you Google the name of the site (it's not a local business), it doesn't show up. I'm guessing that's because it has zero links and content, so my first step is just building out service pages and getting links to those. All of the pages are correctly indexed and it does show up in the search results for the brand name (it's just not first). Does anybody have any input or would take a different approach towards this? Thanks!

text: Hey, can you share the URL of the site? I can take a look

elements.text: Hey, can you share the URL of the site? I can take a look

text: this really depends on who's outranking them and why. like if they have a really generic brand name that's going to be tough.

elements.text: this really depends on who's outranking them and why. like if they have a really generic brand name that's going to be tough.

text: Hmm yeah it is fairly generic. Would you still just approach it from a perspective of building links and content?

elements.text: Hmm yeah it is fairly generic. Would you still just approach it from a perspective of building links and content?

text:
Wait so... the client just "wants it to show up first"?

The first step in this is a lot of education, IMO. If the baseline expectations are that you can simply make this happen because you want to (the same way that if you want a new spatula you go out and buy one), then you're going to set yourself and them up for failure.

Yes, it's technically possible to rank first on Google for things, and it is technically possible that this could be easy-peasy... but mostly likely this will not be the case.

elements.text:
Wait so... the client just "wants it to show up first"?

The first step in this is a lot of education, IMO. If the baseline expectations are that you can simply make this happen because you want to (the same way that if you want a new spatula you go out and buy one), then you're going to set yourself and them up for failure.

Yes, it's technically possible to rank first on Google for things, and it is technically possible that this could be easy-peasy... but mostly likely this will not be the case.

text: Oh I guess I should clarify– they want it to just show up for it's brand name. Sorry about that!

elements.text: Oh I guess I should clarify– they want it to just show up for it's brand name. Sorry about that!

text: And he realizes it will take some time, but because the site is so bare, I want some direction on what to do first

elements.text: And he realizes it will take some time, but because the site is so bare, I want some direction on what to do first

text:
If the sole goal is for it to show up tops for the brand name, we’re battling two things:
1. Enough links with that text to get it to the first page 
2. Enough clicks on that search to keep it there

elements.text: If the sole goal is for it to show up tops for the brand name, we’re battling two things:
Enough links with that text to get it to the first page
Enough clicks on that search to keep it there

text: Ah. Well, in that case increasing links n content is not a bad approach at all. The generic name does present an issue though. In my experience non-generic stuff shows up pretty soon after you've got a few pages (inbound links not really needed). But if you're trying to rank for a competitive keyword, then that's a challenge. Maybe before you go too far down the content build path, do some analysis on the specific word/phrase you want to rank for, and check for comeptitiveness.

elements.text: Ah. Well, in that case increasing links n content is not a bad approach at all. The generic name does present an issue though. In my experience non-generic stuff shows up pretty soon after you've got a few pages (inbound links not really needed). But if you're trying to rank for a competitive keyword, then that's a challenge. Maybe before you go too far down the content build path, do some analysis on the specific word/phrase you want to rank for, and check for comeptitiveness.

text:
Question about event recaps on blogs: my boss wants me to start adding past event recaps to our blog page, but is only looking for a couple of paragraphs and the recording. See here for example: <https://hireology.com/blog/event-recap-how-to-hire-to-retain-talent/>

My concern is that our SEO score will suffer since these "blogs" are very short. Should these be hosted as a /events page to avoid affecting our SEO score or will this not be an issue?

elements.text: Question about event recaps on blogs: my boss wants me to start adding past event recaps to our blog page, but is only looking for a couple of paragraphs and the recording. See here for example:
My concern is that our SEO score will suffer since these "blogs" are very short. Should these be hosted as a /events page to avoid affecting our SEO score or will this not be an issue?

text:
Won’t hurt your SEO at all. If you’re emailing out the recaps or using paid marketing to get eyes on it, the blogs can be helpful.

Now, if you had 10 articles on your website and 2,000 event recaps, that’d be another story.

Changing the subfolder to another folder (/blog to /events) won’t have any impact on SEO either. Google doesn’t keep a score at the folder level.

elements.text:
Won’t hurt your SEO at all. If you’re emailing out the recaps or using paid marketing to get eyes on it, the blogs can be helpful.

Now, if you had 10 articles on your website and 2,000 event recaps, that’d be another story.

Changing the subfolder to another folder (/blog to /events) won’t have any impact on SEO either. Google doesn’t keep a score at the folder level.

text: Okay wonderful, thank you so much!

elements.text: Okay wonderful, thank you so much!

text:
All of the above, plus:

Go into GSC. Click Pages. Add Position to the view. Filter by position, smaller than 20 (to see what’s ranking on page 2, as those results are usually the easiest wins to move to page 1).

Identify a handful of URLs that are getting disproportionate impressions to clicks (CTR). Then see what queries those pages are getting clicks/impressions for, and refresh your selected page based on the keyword you choose.

elements.text:

Go into GSC. Click Pages. Add Position to the view. Filter by position, smaller than 20 (to see what’s ranking on page 2, as those results are usually the easiest wins to move to page 1).

Identify a handful of URLs that are getting disproportionate impressions to clicks (CTR). Then see what queries those pages are getting clicks/impressions for, and refresh your selected page based on the keyword you choose.
